area_name: Margin for Air Wall and Environs

content.description: Corners and roofs up the right side of the crag.
content.location: Start left of the bolted beginning of air of supremacy.

content.description: Bolted line on the far left of the crag. Cool intro moves, then a crux, some bolts, an easy run out, then some more cool moves to the anchor. Once you know where the holds are, this is a pretty fun route.
content.location: Far left side, start in a little alcove with some shale.

content.description: First off, let me admit that this is a project of mine.  I have made it past the pin before the crux, but I don't think I've actually made it to the crux yet.  I fell once on a green camalot, then again on a red camalot higher up.  I took two falls on a #3 camalot past the pin, then tried to protect the next sequence with a #00 C3.  It tore out when I fell again, and I whipped upside-down and injured my heel.  Did I mention that I got stung by a wasp?  My first epic!  Needless to say, this route is continuously difficult, extremely technical, airy, exposed, long, and worth an approach twice as arduous.  Set up a belay on the shale layer and climb over a slabby face towards the bushes above the flake.  Follow the crack up and to the left around an airy bulge, and another airy bulge, and another airy bulge.  Clip a pin next to a hollow sounding flake and climb through another airy bulge.  The Ruckman guide indicates that the crux is right after this section through a steep crack (I didn't make it that far).  Once the crux is finished, you have two options, continue following the crack, or climb diagonally right to the top of the wall and set up a gear belay for your second.
content.protection: Standard rack, doubles recommended.  I saw one fixed pin.  No anchors at the top.
content.location: Start on top of the shale layer to the left (North) of the bolt line and the flake.  Walk off to the North (up and over the top of the wall) or downclimb the slab to the anchors for the other routes.

content.description: The positioning of this is the highlight, perched way above the road with amazing views up canyon and towards the valley. The climbing is not great, with the dihedral being less sustained than it looks from below and with crappier quartzite than most of us are use to in BCC. Good adventure if you're like me and have been looking up at this while driving down canyon and wondering...
content.protection: Doubles .5-3 camalots, a few extra small/micro cams for dihedral, runners and a few quick draws if you want to clip the old pins on the route
content.location: Follow the old aqueduct east a few hundred feet past where you would pick up the bottom of the ridge for the margin of air wall. There is an obvious low angle ridge that you follow up through scrub oak and low angle quartzite slabs. Ditch pack and gear up directly below the last facing dihedral.  Climb 100 feet or so of easy 5th class terrain until you can setup a belay at the base of the corner where there are 2 pitons. Walk off and down to the west. There are chains on the summit for the west facing wall, not sure where they get you down to.

content.description: Ruckman guide calls this one a classic, looks nice.
content.protection: 5 bolts, gear, 2" and 2.5" cams for the roof.
content.location: Far right side of the crag, follow 3 bolts to start.

climbs.name: Air Marshal
climbs.fa: Rollin Grimmett 2019, equipped by DA LeBaron

content.description: Cool airy climbing on this guy. Soar through the beginning crux, and you'll be rewarded with easier (5.12) terrain up crimps and overhanging jugs to the top.
content.protection: 14 bolts to anchor. If you're feeling generous, maybe bring some replacement webbing for the anchor, it was looking a little old.
content.location: Starts in a little corner, under the streaked overhung face, up from there! Crosses the "Margin for Air" line.

pathTokens: Margin for Air Wall and Environs
